questions.text: A 25-day-old baby is brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and lethargy. On examination, he is found to have bulging fontanelles and hypothermia.  Which of the following is the most common cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of neonatal meningitis and Escherichia coli is the most common cause of this condition.

The causes of neonatal meningitis in decreasing order of frequency are: 

  • Escherichia coli
  • Group B Streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes

Empirical treatment of neonatal meningitis is with ampicillin + 3rd generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of meningitis in a 30-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of meningitis in patients aged 2-50 years is Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

The common causes of meningitis in this age group include:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Group B streptococci
  • Hemophilus influenzae
  • Listeria monocytogenes

questions.text: A 66-year-old patient presents with fever, neck rigidity, and headache for the past 3 days. He has a history of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer for which he had received intrathecal chemotherapy via an Ommaya reservoir 10 days ago. On examination, Kernig and Brudzinski's signs are positive. Which organism is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of acute bacterial meningitis. This condition is most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus in a patient with an Ommaya reservoir.

An Ommaya reservoir is an intraventricular catheter system used for the delivery of drugs into the cerebrospinal fluid. S. aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are important causes of meningitis that occurs following invasive neuro-surgical procedures, or as a complication of the use of Ommaya reservoirs. S aureus is a more common cause than CoNS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia and neck rigidity since the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. During examination, the following sign is elicited. What is the therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The sign being elicited here is Kernig's sign and this along with the given clinical features are suggestive of acute bacterial meningitis. Empirical treatment with cefepime, vancomycin and ampicillin is recommended for patients on immunomodulatory drugs as they are at risk for Listeria infection.

Risk factors for Listeria meningitis include:

  • Age>50
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic illness
  • Malignancy
  • Immunosuppressive therapy

questions.text: A 21-year-old female complains of fever, headache and vomiting from the past 3 days. She has been living in the army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. On examination, she has neck stiffness and a maculopapular rash was noted over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is false about the disease she's likely suffering from?

choices.text: Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin
It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease
Metronidazole is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of meningococcal meningitis and the drug of choice is a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone. Chloramphenicol is used in patients with penicillin allergy. 

It is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococci. Outbreaks usually occur in mass gatherings such as in army camps or hostel dorms.

The risk of infection is increased in patients with terminal complement deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia and hyposplenism. This is because opsonization by complement is a major mechanism by which the bacteria is cleared from the blood.

Characteristic clinical findings include:

  • Maculopapular or purpuric rash
  • Shock due to capillary leak
  • Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome)

Rifampicin, ciprofloxacin and cephalosporins can be used to treat carriers.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever and altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.

Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.

S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organisms of community-acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin-resistant and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community-acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of:

  • Dexamethasone
  • Third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime)
  • Vancomycin
  • Acyclovir - HSV encephalitis is the main differential
  • Doxycycline - during tick season.

Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime provides better coverage for susceptible S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae and group B streptococci and good coverage for N. meningitidis. Cefepime is a broad-spectrum fourth-generation cephalosporin with activity similar to that of cefotaxime or ceftriaxone against S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis with additional greater activity against Enterobacter species and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin is used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts. Ceftriaxone and rifampicin are also used.

Antibiotic chemoprophylaxis among close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease is recommended to prevent secondary cases.

  • Rifampin - was earlier used widely, but is not optimal due to the high risk of adverse events, emerging resistance, and the need for compliance for four doses.
  • Ciprofloxacin - widely used as a single oral dose, but it cannot be given in pregnancy and those below 18 years of age.
  • Ceftriaxone - can be given in pregnancy and all ages as a single IM or IV dose. However, reduced susceptibility of isolates to ceftriaxone has occasionally been reported.

Recommended chemoprophylaxis for high-risk close contacts for meningococcal meningitis:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of fever for 1 month presents with headache and ataxia. Imaging reveals dilated ventricles and significant basal exudates. Which of the following would most likely be seen in the CSF?
questions.solution:
The features and imaging findings are suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. CSF analysis would likely show lymphocytosis, low glucose and high protein.

If the CSF is allowed to stand, a 'spider’s web clot' or 'cobweb' coagulam may form due to the high level of protein.

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is:

Opening pressure – Increased

Proteins- Mildly increased

Glucose – Normal

Lymphocytes – Increased.
questions.solution:
The given symptoms cluster of fever, vomiting, and neck stiffness is suggestive of meningitis. A CSF analysis showing increased opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, mildly increased protein, and normal glucose is suggestive of viral meningitis. Among the given options, Coxsackie (Option D) is the only viral cause of meningitis. 

Other options:

Option A: Tuberculous meningitis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with low glucose.

Option B: Bacterial meningitis shows neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose.

Option C: Fungal meningitis shows lymphocytic/neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose.

questions.text: A college student presents with fever, headache, and confusion. Lumbar puncture was positive for HSV DNA, detected by PCR. An MRI brain is done to localize the lesions. Which area on the brain is most likely to show lesions?
questions.solution:
The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis has been the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe.

Investigation of choice includes HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR. 

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with fever, headache, seizures and aphasia. MRI shows hyperintensity in the left frontotemporal region. Which of the following would likely be seen in the CSF analysis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis and the CSF analysis would likely show 100 RBC/microliter. HSV encephalitis is associated with hemorrhagic necrosis of inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe resulting in significant number of RBCs in the CSF.

It is caused by both HSV 1 and HSV 2. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality, and behavioral changes.

CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels and normal glucose concentration. EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges.

The drug of choice for the condition is acyclovir.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with progressive dementia of recent onset presents with intermittent irregular jerky movements. The EEG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and EEG point towards a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). The EEG shows periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.

CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is fatal within 1 year of onset of symptoms.

Patients present with myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar or visual disturbances and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction (hypokinesia). Insomnia, apathy and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Management is mainly supportive.

Note: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.
